Indispensable Edit Guy: Doug_G

The burnished knights on their horses were being savaged by the club-wielding brute whose deep rumbling laugh frayed the nerves of even most stalwart. The creature stood more than twice the height of an average man wore foul-smelling leathers and an eye patch made of human skin. Its teeth had grown out and over its rubbery lips to form yellowed and broken daggers flecked with old blood and gristle. It smashes a company of cavalry attempting to release the pressure on a company of foot soldiers who had been scattered with a few great swings of that fire-hardened club. The soldiers fight back but are simply no match for this threat.

"Come beast, look upon doom!" The bloody valley shook with the power and resonance of this new voice. The giant turns at the sound, seeing a man of hard muscles and snaking blue tattoos step free from the forest. He wears a vicious black helmet of crude spikes and jagged metal. In his hands he swings an axe spotted with the blackish blood of the giant kind. He strides forward, like a rolling avalanche, batting away the giant's minions; his axe hewing a lethal path until he stands before the giant. The man lets out a mighty roar that shatters the brief quiet on the war field. The sound crashes upon the minions and sends them fleeing in a blind panic. The giant's heart grows faint at the sound, and drops its club to cover its ears. "May death take you!"

The Wrathful Berserker cut deep into the cowering figure before him.

The theme of this build is to make the best use of terrifying rage. The Wrathful Berserker then follows up his rage effect with liberal use of devastating criticals against those who are terrified. Nothing can withstand this particular build except those who have high saves against the fear effect of the rage.

Once a victim is terrified, they cannot defend themselves against the blows of the berserker's axe. Even without the devastating critical, the damage is still enough to hurt most creatures for the duration of the effect. The damage can be even higher if traveling in a group of clerics, wizards, and/or sorcerers who can supplement or enhance the Berserker's efforts. The Wrathful Berserker's weapon preference is the great axe, and he is a true embodiment of fear.

In terms of items, he should equip heavy armor type; full plate is preferred along with the great axe. Other items really don't matter since this build is made to not to rely on any stat boosters, but if that is wanted, anything with CON and STR and/or CHA boost is best to use. If you are going to encounter a creature that is powerful, such as a boss monster on the server, you will need to get items that will heal you.

Background, Analysis and Comments by Author

Equipment
Greataxe
Full Plate

Wrathful Berserker's Advantages
High HP
Can easily defeat anyone with his Devastating Critical whenever they fail their saving throws against the fear effect of Terrifying Rage; even with saves they will still have to overcome Devastating Critical
Barbarian Speed

Secondary Advantages
Can reduce the creature's AC using Taunt skills that have been maximized
High Discipline
Thundering Rage
Paladins or Blackguard can't use their smite evil/good
Sneaking characters cannot avoid the terrifying rage effect; once the saves are failed, the berserker will know where they are.

Wrathful Berserker's Disadvantages
Low saves
Low AC

Secondary Disadvantages
Cannot fight dragons due to the fear aura (this can be avoided if someone in the party casts any spells that makes him immune to fear effects)
Cannot see any sneaking creatures/characters (can be avoided, look above)

posts.author: Stagmeister
posts.content:
Following in the grand tradition of Mick and Valerfor offering updated versions of some of our legacy builds, I thought I'd re-examine the Wrathful Berserker. I've kept the underpinning principles the same, but tightened up on a few things - including adding a third class. Mostly it's marginal, but his AB, AC (though still sucky), saves, DC for both Dev Crit and Terrifying Rage are higher, and he has increased his skill points. Of course, there are some losses as well as gains. He loses 28 hit points, 1 Greater Rage, along with some frankly superfluous feats and the ability to be evil. I've also given him a heavy flail, because I like them (and they're great when Rage and Dev Crit don't work, against undead, for example), but a great sword/axe is still viable. I believe it is an improvement, but I'll let you be the judge of that.

posts.author: Mick Dagger
posts.content:
Your version is better, Stag! Better AB, AC, saves and critical skills - and a more focused build altogether.
If I should suggest anything at all, it would be to add a Tumble class as a minor class for skill dumps, to add valuable AC to this two-hander build. Bard (a non-lawful class to boot) could also improve the Spellcraft and the saves vs spells with the same investment in skill points.
You would of course lose the Fighter/CoT synergy with improved saves together with EWS, and a possible XP penalty may become an issue.

posts.author: Stagmeister
posts.content:
Thanks Mick!

To avoid that xp penalty, and totally reverse the alignment, Assassin might well be viable. Something like a Barbarian 32/ Fighter 6/ Assassin 2 (both in epic levels), with a B16/ F4 split pre-epic. I appreciate the cross-classed skill investment in Hide and MS, but more points would be available in any case. Toughness could be lost pre-epic (still leaving a very healthy HP pool), but I'd have to drop 2 Great Strengths in epic levels, bringing the Dev Crit DC down to 39 and losing 1 AB. Barbarian 32 gives one more bonus feat, so I'd be losing 2 CoT ones, but I don't really see the point in dropping AS and EP, when AC already needs attention and 1 AB would still be lost. And I'd rather keep the TR DC as high as possible.

Worth pursuing?

posts.author: Stagmeister
posts.content:
I've had a look at adding a Tumble class, and yes, it does help defensively. However, the prime focus of this beast is offence, making use of TR to scythe away the chaff, then following up with KD and Dev Crit. The hope is to get in, get it done quick, and get out. A deep HP pool and DR helps with those blows he does take, and travelling in the company of a buffer and healer would aid significantly.

Which is my long-winded way of saying that I think I'll keep him as is.
